description: {"blocks":[{"key":"eaj00","text":"This protocol describes how to collect and care for Streblospio benedicti. This protocol outlines best practices for sample collection, adult worm care, crossing worms, and raising worm larvae to adults. Additionally, we have information on how to ship worms and a list of recommended supplies. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":52,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"rd7f","text":"Filter the seawater using a 0.22 um vacuum filter into 1 L bottles","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7b8mu","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"emi9l","text":"Making and Maintaining Algae Stocks","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ed7ut","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2g8qh","text":"Use a disposable pipette to place 3 ml of Tetraselmis stock into an autoclaved flask, 3 ml of Rhodomonas stock into another. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cahi0","text":"Add 150 ml of Alga Grow made in artificial seawater (30 ppt)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnfm5","text":"Top flask with a sterile cotton ball and aluminum foil","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3q34e","text":"Label flask with date and contents","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cbr0c","text":"Leave in a window sill or 12-hr light cycle incubator at room temperature (or 20C) for 3-5 days to allow algae to grow","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7j0sv","text":"Allow stocks to grow for 7-10 days. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6bng","text":"After 10 days, reserve old algae in 50 ml falcon tubes and freeze. These can be autoclaved and then added to lab mud stocks as needed. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8j110","text":"Worms are in glass finger bowls or plastic six well plates.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1k96o","text":"These bowls and plates are placed on clear acrylic trays to prevent spilling of seawater into the incubator, while also allowing light to be distributed to all plates and bowls. 1 population or experiment per tray. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"73o2n","text":"It is best to keep stacks of plates to a maximum of three.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3nb38","text":"Clean the incubator shelves monthly with 10% bleach solution. Make sure to rinse well and dry. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"67jlg","text":"Replace air filters in the incubator as required by the manufacturer. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1acso","text":"Test the salinity of the water you are collecting in.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6pb8a","text":"Coarse sieve (4.75mm): Sieve collected mud into a new bucket. Reserve the flow-through and discard the contents of the sieve","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aho0b","text":"Fine sieve (600 um): Sieve the coarse-sieved mud. Flow-through can be reserved for mud collection. Reserve the contents of the fine sieve. Move sieve contents to tupperware containers. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a5s8a","text":"From your tupperware search for Streblospio worms in your sample using forceps under a dissecting microscope. Note: Take about 1 tablespoon from your tupperware and dilute with seawater to look for worms. Repeat until the entire sample has been searched through. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qnhq","text":"Place the worms into small glass bowls or 6-well plates. Add enough mud to cover the bottom of the plate or bowl. If the site salinity is below 30 ppt, gradually increase salinity by 5 ppt per day until you reach desired salinity. Changing the salinity too fast will shock the worms and they may die. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dsm9i","text":"For example, if the collection site was 15 ppt, use 15 ppt when you initially plate them. Increase salinity to 20 ppt the next day, 25 ppt the following, and then finally 30 ppt.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a3s5q","text":"Mark and set aside brooding females to collect life history data and to raise young, if desired. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5o5gg","text":"How to label 6-well plates for field collected worms:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8u3iv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65o9p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"du070","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6n8ef","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8651d","text":"Mud Collection","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eff78","text":"Using a garden spade, scrape the first ~4 cm of mud into a 5-gallon bucket. Walk along the marsh, scraping the first ~4 cm, until the bucket is close to full. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3smka","text":"Coarse sieve (4.75mm): Sieve collected mud into a new bucket. Reserve the flow-through and discard the contents of the sieve. Use seawater to get as much mud off the sides of the bucket as possible. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56aff","text":"Rinse out your original mud bucket. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62t5r","text":"Fine sieve (600 um): Sieve coarse-sieved mud into the original mud bucket. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cvmpv","text":"Allow the fine-sieved throughput to settle for about an hour. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ln39","text":"Carefully decant water off the top of the bucket, or using a bit of aquarium tubing, siphon water off of the mud just until the output starts to run brown.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6pltr","text":"Back in the lab: Allow your mud collection to sit again for 1-12 hours. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70g52","text":" Using a garden spade and funnel, scoop mud into 125 ml nalgene containers.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fnde5","text":"If the bottom of the bucket becomes too thick (notice sand-like particles and lack of fluidity), this mud can be discarded. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fcn62","text":"Once all mud is in containers, they can be frozen in a standard freezer. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3q6s5","text":"Find 6-well plates with worms marked as either male or female (preferably from a handful of different families). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ejv35","text":"Pick 3 males and 3 females from different families.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aj174","text":"Get a new 6-well plate and label the top left corner with the population and “CROSSES” and the top right corner with today’s date. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ta8i","text":"Find your 3 females - check and make sure that they look healthy (no green/blue and not moving slowly) and have plenty of eggs on the side of their body walls. (see Sexing Worms section, if needed)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4oil5","text":"Place each female in a well in the top row of your new plate and label each well with that worm’s family ID. Add about 1-2 ml of mud and fill the wells with ASW. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8srfr","text":"Find your 3 males - Before looking for the worm check and see if there is evidence of spermatophores on the mud’s surface. Try to only use males that look like they have recently made spermatophores. Check and make sure that they look healthy (no green/blue and not moving slowly). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c98pi","text":"Place each male in a well in the bottom row of your plate and label each well with that worm’s family ID. Add about 1-2 ml of mud and fill the wells with ASW. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26iuq","text":"Wait 1-2 days and then check your males for spermatophores. Once a male is making spermatophores, move the female in the well above it to the male’s well. Mark on the tray lid with an arrow that the female has been moved. Clear the female’s original well of mud and water. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jusj","text":"After about 5 days from starting the cross, pull out each worm. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9b10l","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":10,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2g1p1","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"96qod","text":"Released planktotrophic larvae will be swimming at the edge of the well  ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fhmq3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":11,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"686u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"j2lm","text":"If larvae are released or removed, use a glass pipette to move them to a new six well plate with ASW. See this video for an example","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3igt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"g56n","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":36,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dv2di","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"54p9e","text":"Once the worm is out of the tube, wait for it to steady (it will likely thrash and swim in an infinity/figure-eight symbol pattern once out of the tube). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9stud","text":"Once settled, zoom in on the worm’s body wall to look for eggs. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4dg5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":37,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1puac","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58ls7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":38,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4sbpi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"uqpi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":39,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c652v","text":"Make sure you can count individual eggs and the body wall is not just whitish. Male worms will have a sparkly white hue on their body wall sometimes.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3dqrv","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ec3mo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":40,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9nfel","text":"If there are distinct eggs on the worm, the worm can be moved back to its original well, and the lid marked with a female symbol.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7h89f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a71k6","text":"Male ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1fe65","text":"At a light microscope, focus on your worm of interest’s well or plate","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2cmj","text":"First, scan the surface of the mud for spermatophores. They should look like the structures below. You might have to zoom in 3-5x to properly see them. See Image 26 \u0026 27 for examples. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44shq","text":"Once you have located spermatophores, you can mark the worm’s lid with a male symbol. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"evcfl","text":"If unsure whether your worm is male or female but it looks to be mature (i.e. you see a shiny white body wall, but didn’t see any spermatophores, or you think you saw a brood pouch but no eggs) you can mark the worm with a “$” to signify it is a mature worm, but you could not 100% say it was male or female. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dot77","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3m1dd","text":"How to Ship Worms","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4jrgp","text":"Test salinity of the seawater from your sample","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpmfq","text":"Take samples collected from the field. Scoop approximately 1 tablespoon of collected mud into a large petri dish and fill with seawater at the appropriate salinity. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cuh9m","text":"At a microscope, search for Streblospio in the subset of your sample. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9tjr5","text":"Put worms into a well in a 6-well plate with a little bit of mud (just enough to cover them) and fill the well with seawater. Repeat until you’ve gone through your entire sample. (Note: set aside brooding females if desired)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"botgl","text":"Put 5 worms in each well (30 total per plate).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5hc1","text":"Let worms sit for about a day. Revisit the wells and remove any dead worms. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"btbeb","text":"Put worms of 1 plate (~30 worms) into a 50 ml falcon tube. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4pqr","text":"To the tube, add about 15-20 ml of mud and 20 ml of seawater. Close the lid. Wrap lid with lab tape or parafilm. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgtp1","text":"Label the tube with the location, date collected, salinity of the water the worms are currently in, and any other pertinent information (i.e. females were noticed). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a2bvj","text":"Pack tubes in a styrofoam shipping box in a cardboard box. If warm outside, pack with an ice-pack. Put a piece of plastic or packing material so the tubes do not sit directly on the ice-pack.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8mp1l","text":"Ship worms to the desired lab!
